text:
People often fail to engage
in healthy behaviors.

We can help people follow
through on these behaviors

and live healthier lives
if we help them turn
those behaviors into habits.
Now, how do we do this?

One line of thinking is
that habits work best

if people engage in
the desired behavior
under routine conditions.

For example, at the
same time of day.

However, my research has shown
that this strategy does not
always work.

Let's say a person
wants to exercise more

and 2:00 PM is generally
the best time of day.

Unfortunately, life is
going to get in the way.

They'll have a work meeting
or a personal appointment
at that time.

In this case, it's
better to help

people form a flexible,
resilient habit, exercising

when there happens to be
a break in their schedule.

This is the type
of habit that will

have a lasting impact
on health behaviors

when routines
conflict with people's
hectic day-to-day lives.
